title: Cell Theory & Microscopy Basics
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Foundations of cell biology: the three tenets of cell theory, historical development, and the microscopy techniques that made cellular discovery possible.
learningIntentions: Students can state the three tenets of cell theory and explain their significance.
Students can sequence the historical discoveries that led to cell theory (Hooke, Leeuwenhoek, Schleiden, Schwann, Virchow).
Students can distinguish between living and non-living entities using cell theory criteria.
Students can identify appropriate microscopy techniques for different specimens.

engagementHook.title: The Invisible Kingdom
engagementHook.content: Show Robert Hooke's original cork drawing (1665). Ask: 'Hooke saw tiny boxes and called them 'cells' after monk's rooms. But he only saw dead plant cell walls. What would he have seen with a modern electron microscope? And what crucial feature of living cells did he completely miss?'

keyConcepts.definition: All living organisms are composed of one or more cells. The cell is the fundamental unit of structure and function in all living things.
All cells arise from pre-existing cells through cell division. This disproves spontaneous generation.
Cells contain hereditary information (DNA) which is passed from cell to cell during division.
Uses visible light and glass lenses. Maximum resolution ~200 nanometres. Can view living cells.
Uses electron beams. Resolution ~0.2 nanometres. Requires dead, thinly sectioned specimens. Shows internal structure.
Uses electron beams to scan surface. Resolution ~3 nanometres. Creates 3D surface images. Requires specimen coating.

misconceptions.correction: Hooke only saw dead plant cell walls in cork. Living cells were first observed by Leeuwenhoek in 1674.
Virchow's 'omnis cellula e cellula' (1855) took 190 years after Hooke to fully establish.
Viruses are not cells—they lack metabolism and cannot reproduce independently. They challenge the universality of cell theory.

contentSections.title: The Three Tenets of Cell Theory
contentSections.content: Cell theory, first proposed in the 19th century, is one of biology's fundamental unifying principles. The three tenets state: (1) All living things are composed of cells, (2) The cell is the basic unit of life, and (3) All cells come from pre-existing cells. These statements seem obvious today but required centuries of observation and technological advancement to establish.
keyPoints: The cell is the smallest unit that can exist as an independent living entity
Cell division transmits genetic information to daughter cells
Spontaneous generation (life from non-life) is rejected by modern cell theory
contentSections.example: When you cut your skin, new skin cells divide and grow from the edges to heal the wound—not from the air or bandage spontaneously generating cells.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why is a virus not considered a cell, even though it contains genetic material?

activities.title: Cell Theory Tenets & Implications
activities.description: Match each tenet of cell theory to its scientific implication.
activities.learningObjective: Understand the significance of each cell theory tenet.

items.text: All living things are composed of cells
items.match: Defines the fundamental unit of life—nothing smaller than a cell can live independently

items.text: The cell is the basic unit of structure and function
items.match: Cells can exist as independent organisms (unicellular) or as part of tissues (multicellular)

items.text: All cells arise from pre-existing cells
items.match: Disproves spontaneous generation—life cannot emerge from non-living matter

multipleChoice.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three tenets of cell theory?
options: All living organisms are composed of cells
Cells are the basic unit of structure and function
All cells arise from pre-existing cells
multipleChoice.rationale: Prokaryotic cells do not have a nucleus. The three tenets concern the universality of cells, their functional importance, and their origin from division—not specific structures.

multipleChoice.question: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek's contribution to cell theory was:
options: First observation of living cells and microorganisms
Proposing that all plants are composed of cells
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: First observation of living cells and microorganisms
multipleChoice.rationale: Leeuwenhoek (1674) observed 'animalcules' in pond water—living bacteria and protists. Hooke named cells (1665); Schleiden proposed plant cell theory (1838); Virchow disproved spontaneous generation (1855).

multipleChoice.question: A biologist wants to observe the internal structure of mitochondria. Which microscope should they use?
multipleChoice.rationale: TEM provides the highest resolution (~0.2nm) and shows internal structures of thinly sectioned specimens. SEM shows surface only; light microscope lacks resolution for organelle internals.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why a virus is considered a challenging case for cell theory, referring to two specific tenets. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Viruses contain genetic material (DNA or RNA) but are not composed of cells
1 mark: Viruses cannot reproduce independently—they require host cells
1 mark: They challenge 'all living things are composed of cells' and 'cells arise from cells'
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating viruses are 'dead' rather than 'non-cellular' or 'acellular'

definitions: Cell Theory Tenet 1: All living organisms are composed of one or more cells.
Cell Theory Tenet 2: The cell is the basic unit of structure and function in all living things.
Cell Theory Tenet 3: All cells arise from pre-existing cells through cell division (omnis cellula e cellula).
Compound light microscope: Resolution ~200nm, can view living cells.
TEM: Resolution ~0.2nm, shows internal structures, requires dead specimens.
keyPoints: Hooke (1665) named cells; Leeuwenhoek (1674) saw living cells
Schleiden (1838) + Schwann (1839) = all organisms composed of cells
Virchow (1855) completed theory: cells come from cells
Viruses challenge cell theory—they are acellular
diagrams: Comparison of light vs electron microscopy capabilities

shortAnswer: Viruses are challenging cases for cell theory because they contain genetic material but are not composed of cells, violating Tenet 1. Additionally, they cannot reproduce independently—they must infect host cells to replicate—challenging Tenet 3 that all cells arise from pre-existing cells. Viruses exist in a biological grey area: they show some life characteristics (genetic material, evolution) but lack cellular structure and independent metabolism.
